titleInfo.title: Willie Blount's lessee v. Solomon Geron et al (1823) map exhibit

mods.abstract: Survey plat of William Blount's 5000 acres in Roane County on both sides of the Emory River at the fork. Mountains are depicted in Armstrong's usual style -- watercolored in grey. Survey call points are labeled and the course of the river is indicated by an arrow. Armstrong' distinct fleur-de-lis indicates north.

On January 1, 1812, Willie Blount leased this plot of land to a John Den (a 19th century form of John Doe) to farm for ten years. John Den, the unnamed lessee, accused a Richard Fen (another 19th century form of John Doe) of forcibly coming onto the land, "wrong[ed]" him and did five hundred dollars worth of damage. At some point in the case the charge of ejectment was added to the original bill, the addition of which created a constitutionality issue. The case made it to the Tennessee Supreme Court where Justice Robert Whyte ruled that there was no precedent for the attachment of ejectment to a case of equity and that "this court will not establish such a precedent."
